_prev_prog_3.Description: Monson, LLC complies with the prevention program level 3 requirements found in the WISHA PSM standard contained in WAC 296-67.  This program is organized into the following elements: 1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program wherever possible; 2) Training is provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and is periodically reviewed to ensure the adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to starting a new or restarting a modified process to ensure that the impacts of the changes are addressed; 11) Incident investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's Emergency Action Plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state, and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

_prev_prog_3.Description: Monson, LLC complies with the prevention program requirements found in the WISHA PSM standard contained in WAC 296-67.  This program is organized into the following elements: 1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program whenever possible; 2) Training is provided or operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and is periodically reviewed to ensure the adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to starting a new or re-starting a modified process to ensure that the impacts of the changes are addressed; 11) Incident Investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and incidents that could endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives. 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the Plant's Emergency Action Plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state, and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Monson, LLC

Selah, WA 98942

 



RMP Executive Summary below:

 

Monson, LLC has four (over 10,000#) anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems to quickly chill, pack and store under a controlled atmosphere, a variety of fruit products. The systems have computerized process control systems that monitor system performance and control their operation.



Anhydrous Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in these systems.  Anhydrous Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent ammonia odor that is an irritant to the eyes, nose and throat. Anhydrous ammonia is normally shipped as a liquefied compressed gas and is present in portions of the refrigeration system as a liquid under pressure. Please refer to onsite Process Safety Information for current ammonia inventories.



In order to protect its' employees, the public, and the environment, Monson, LLC has an integrated process safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur.  The program is designed to comply with WISHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) found in WAC 296-67 and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations found in 40 CFR Part 68. 



The Monson, LLC plant has an Emergency Action Plan that addresses the response procedures necessary for a release of anhydrous ammonia from a refrigeration system.  The compressor rooms are equipped with ammonia gas detectors that alarm if ammonia is detected at a concentration of 35ppm.  The refrigeration systems are designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves.  In case of an accidental release, calls would be made to the Selah Police and Selah Fire Departments and to the Yakima County Emergency Services to assist in the response. 



During the last five years, there have been no reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia. Should there be an accidental release when no one is on the premises, it would be detected by the ammonia gas detectors that are connected to

a computer control system.  Ammonia gas detectors are installed and the computer monitors all areas where ammonia could possibly be.  When the control system detects ammonia it activates the alarm and dials emergency numbers for designated refrigeration personnel. 



Monson, LLC makes daily inspections of the ammonia refrigeration systems to determine if there are any potential problems; in addition,  preventive maintenance programs are in place and inspections, tests and maintenance are completed by qualified site and contractor ammonia refrigeration technicians.



As a result of the revision of the Process Safety Management Plans for Refrigeration Systems 1, 2, 3 and 4 and the Risk Management Plan for Refrigeration Systems 1, 2, 3 and 4, all aspects of the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration systems have been reviewed and approved by the PSM Committee.
